history.content: Honestly you are better off pursuing LSCS unless you are into electrical engineering... Simultaneous degrees are extremely difficult and if you are interested in CS, completely unnecessary

Unfortunately, it is very difficult to major in EECS if you did not enter the university as an Engineering student. More information can be found at: http://engineering.berkeley.edu/academics/majors-minors/simultaneous-degrees

  • At least two semesters have been completed at Berkeley at the time of application.
  • The planned program includes all requirements for both majors and colleges.
  • No more than two upper division courses (used to satisfy major requirements) may overlap between the two programs. There is no limit on the number of courses used to satisfy breadth or humanities requirements that may overlap.
  • If a ninth semester (or fifth semester for transfer students) is required to complete the simultaneous degree, this request must be made at the time of application. Requests for this additional semester are generally approved; consult with your Engineering Student Services (ESS) adviser for more information.
  • Applicants from a school or college other than engineering must have an overall and technical GPA of 3.0 or higher. (The minimum GPA for consideration is 3.0. Applications are reviewed for acceptance by the department to which a student applies, and some have a higher GPA requirement.)
  • Applicants from a school or college other than engineering must meet all change of college application criteria and, in most cases, must submit their simultaneous degree application no later than the end of the sophomore year. Though applicants remain in their current college, they are still applying to the College of Engineering. We have the same criteria for admission, whether applying for change of college or to complete a simultaneous degree. Visit the change of college section of our website to learn the application criteria.
    • There are rare cases in which we would accept a simultaneous degree application during summer after the fourth semester. The student would need to have some extenuating circumstances for why the deadline was missed. We never, however, accept simultaneous degree applications for a non-COE student once the fifth semester has begun. We should probably make that more clear online.
  • Applications for simultaneous degrees must be submitted at least two semesters before the anticipated date of graduation. In most cases, applicants from other colleges must submit by the end of their sophomore year. Students who cannot meet the sophomore year deadline should meet with an ESS adviser to determine if a late application can be considered.
  • The application must be approved by the deans of both colleges/schools to which you are applying. Review the instructions on the application for information on obtaining the necessary approvals and signatures, and consult with your ESS adviser if you have questions

Let me know if you have anymore questions!

"There are rare cases in which we would accept a simultaneous degree application during summer after the fourth semester. The student would need to have some extenuating circumstances for why the deadline was missed. If we aren't a COE student, can we still meet with an ESS advisor to find out if a late application will be considered?

history.content:
If I intend to obtain simultaneous degrees in EECS and the Practice of Art and I'm currently in L&S, in order to obtain simultaneous degrees do I have to apply by my 4th semester? How do I go about this?

EDIT: I am really interested in electrical engineering. I was thinking about just doing L&S CS while going through all of the requirements for the EECS major, but then if I'm doing all the same work then why shouldn't I get the actual major that I am working towards?

My only concern right now is that I know that my technical GPA will be above 3.4 or 3.6 but it will most likely not be 3.8 or higher by the time I can actually apply in Fall 2016. This is because I am taking three technical classes per semester alongside 3 classes that fulfill college requirements or art major requirements both this semester and next semester. Is it possible that there could be an exception in the GPA requirement in light of my workload? I am also a spring admit so i've been trying to catch up.
